results:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about "Mistrz i Małgorzata" (The Master and Margarita) and censorship in communist Poland and the Soviet Union.

## Censorship of "The Master and Margarita" in the Soviet Union

The novel was first published (in a censored version) in the monthly magazine "Moskwa" (issues 11/1966 and 1/1967). When the novel was published then in an incomplete version, censorship removed about 14,000 words. It was published in a censored version in 1966-1967, and in an almost complete version in 1973.

The complete work by Bulgakov appeared only in 1969 in the magazine "Posiev" and in book version in 1973.

## Publication in Poland

The first Polish edition, translated by Witold Dąbrowski and Irena Lewandowska, based on the censored Soviet edition, was published in 1969. In Poland, the first edition (1969) was published by the State Publishing Institute.

For the first time into Polish, the translation was done in 1969 by Irena Lewandowska and Witold Dąbrowski, and this translation is the best known. In 1995, Andrzej Drawicz undertook the translation. In Poland this year, a new translation of the novel by Grzegorz, Leokadia and Igor Przebindów was published by Kraków's Znak publishing house.

## Special Editions Showing Censorship

There have been special editions that highlight the censorship interventions:

This edition, prepared according to the 1969 edition by Possev-Verlag, Frankfurt/Main, is unique because all the interventions of Soviet censorship have been marked in it.

## Impact of Censorship on Bulgakov's Life and Work

Bulgakov lived in a totalitarian state, saw the development of Stalin's cult, the omnipotence of officials and the absurdity of everyday life in the USSR. The novel is a reaction to this reality: it shows fear, opportunism and enslavement of society through grotesque and fantasy. Censorship and conflicts with the literary environment also left their mark - the Master, a persecuted writer in the work, is the author's alter ego fighting for creative freedom.

Bulgakov sent the first chapter to the Nedra publishing house, but without much hope that censorship would allow publication.

The search results reveal that "The Master and Margarita" faced significant censorship in the Soviet Union, with thousands of words removed from the initial publication. The book's journey to Polish readers was also affected by this censorship, as the first Polish translation was based on the incomplete Soviet edition.
